MONTCO RESEARCH PRODUCTS, INC.

EPA ID # 100000168953

RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM RE-eSUBMITTALAL

2014 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155                                                                        

Montco Research Products, Inc. (Montco) operates its plant at 209 Janice Drive, P.O. Box 235, Hollister, FL  32147.  The plant has quantities of a regulated hazardous chemical, anhydrous hydrogen chloride (CAS # 7647-01-0), above the 6,000 pound EPA and OSHA threshold.  Montco has a unified Risk Management Program (RMP) as it is also subject to OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM).  



1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (A)

Montco  prevents accidental releases through classroom and on the job training of operating personnel and ongoing inspection and maintenance of the hydrogen chloride gas storage transfer and injection system.  The facility maintains an ongoing emergency response program that prepares for safe evacuation and timely response by trained personnel.  The plant program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.



1.2.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (A) (1)

Montco has a management system in place which is lead by the Vice President .  The Vice President oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with other plant-specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.



1.3.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)

Montco maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program. The program addresses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, as well as RMP elements, needed to implement the program

, and the like elements in place in the plants OSHA PSM program.  These are maintained by the Montco Plant Document Management System (DMS).



1.4.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT MONTCO RESEARCH PRODUCTS INC., FLORIDA SITE (B)  

Montco employs 10 full-time and one part time employee engaged in plant operations.  Hydrogen chloride is a raw ingredient used as part of the chemical manufacturing process.



1.5.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)    

The site is owned and operated by Montco and is managed by Montco staff.  The site is located at 209 Janice Drive, P.O. Box 235, Hollister, Putnam County, Florida.   The 100-acre site is located at the end of Janice Drive.

The Plant includes a separate anhydrous hydrogen chloride storage area.  Up to two tube trailers can be stored at one time.



The boundaries of the hydrogen chloride system subject to the RMP, and like PSM, regulation include the Bulk Hydrogen Chloride Storage, Feed Control system, associated vent makeup, exhaust systems, and the hydrogen chloride system units.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.



1.6.    MONTCO RESEARCH PRODUCTS AND ANHYDROUS HYDROGEN CHLORIDE

Montco uses hydrogen chloride gas in a reaction/distillation process in order to produce 1-Chloromethylnapthalene and Ethyl Benzyl Chloride.  A maximum quantity of 42,000 lbs. of anhydrous hydrogen chloride is stored on site in two compressed gas tube trailers.  Each trailer contains up to seven tubes with a capacity of 3,000 pounds of hydrogen chloride each.  A Risk Management Plan has been developed as required and is maintained in order to reduce the possibility of an accidental release of hydrogen chloride gas from the system.



2.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT

A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the environment, the public and th

e Montco staff and equipment.  The distance to a hydrogen chloride endpoint concentration of the gas was determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of hydrogen chloride was determined, and sensitive receptors such as residences were identified.  The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios-a "worst case" and an "alternative case".  The five-year EPA accident history for the hydrogen chloride system was included in the hazards assessment.  (Zero EPA accidents to date.)

The "worst case release" scenario is defined by EPA, which states that "the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutes" due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as "more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario".  Montco staff based this alternate case on the findings of the Process Hazards Analysis.



Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the hydrogen chloride released before its concentration decreases to the "toxic endpoint."  The EPA specified endpoint for hydrogen chloride is 0.030 mg/l.  The endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the "maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individual's ability to take protective action."  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined.  The 2010 census data was used "to estimate the population potentially affected."



2.1.    WORST CASE   (C) (1)

Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions and EPA's RMP Comp Program.  A total of 3,000 pounds are re

leased over 10 minutes yielding a 300 pound per minute release rate.  (Release data is kept on site in the  Process Safety Information)



2.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (C) (2)

The alternative release scenario involves the failure of the regulator of the pressure system or the tubing/valves connected to one of the 3,000 pound tube containers.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating a 0.03 square inch hole in the tube, a pipe, or even the container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp guidance demonstrated the rate of hydrogen chloride release is 100.0 lb. /minutes for a period of 30 minutes releasing a total of 3,000 pounds of hydrogen chloride.  (Release data is kept on site in the  Process Safety Information)



3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)

Montco's accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM  and RMP programs have been in place and effectively used for many years.  It is part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall plant-wide program and the site-specific PSM/RMP program.  The second is the hydrogen chloride specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the Palatka Fire Rescue/HazMat Team and Putnam County's Fire/Rescue Department and the Regional LEPC.



3.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (D) (1)

Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:

Montco has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 

The document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  

Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphas awareness of the hazardous and toxic

properties of all chemicals used.  Refresher training is conducted annually or as required by regulation.

Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 

Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident. 

Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response. 

Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 

Contractors must meet Montco's high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.  Additionally, Montco demands training of contractors to the hazards and emergency response to meet our standards. 



3.2.    HYDROGEN CHLORIDESPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)



3.2.1.    Hydrogen Chloride-Specific Operating Safety Information

Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the hydrogen chloride specific program.



3.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the hydrogen chloride process. 

Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified hydrogen chloride system.   

Specific emergency response procedures for hydrogen chloride releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures. See the Emergency Response Program book. 

Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for hydrogen chloride is conducted annually. 

Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the hydrogen chloride system.



3.2.3.    Facility Design

The hydrogen chloride storage area is located in an open area northeast of the plant operating area. The plant and support equipment of the h

ydrogen chloride storage area and feed control meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The storage and control area has an open air natural ventilation system.  The reaction emissions vent water tank scrubber which is capable of neutralizing over 3,000 pounds of hydrogen chloride.  This is followed by a dual packed columns vent scrubber.  A caustic solution is circulated over the column packing and neutralizes any hydrogen chloride gases.



3.2.4.    Equipment Design

There two hydrogen chloride pipe systems, both are under pressure.  The hydrogen chloride piping system is made of hydrogen chloride compatible stainless steel pipes, stainless steel tubes or equipment.  These materials include compatible non-metallic compound (not corroded by hydrogen chloride) rated to 1,000 psig.  The maximum pressure of the hydrogen chloride in the high pressure system is 650 psig. There are six or seven 3,000 pound tube containers on each tube trailer.  One tube is in service and the other five or six are on valved off, ie in standby. 

The system has a nitrogen purge system for both pressure testing and clearing the hydrogen chloride lines to and from the tube trailer to the reactors.

The reactors operate under negative pressure and as discussed above vent to multiple a scrubber system. 



4.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)

The plant has been hydrogen chloride reportable and release free since 1992 to the present, 22 years.  There have been no EPA accidental releases of anhydrous hydrogen chloride at Montco Research Products in the last ten years.



5.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)

Emergency response procedures are contained in the Plant Emergency Response Policy that is coordinated with the City of Palatka, Putnam County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response "decision tree" and a notification plan.  Emergency response drills including evacuations are conducted by Montco staff.  Emergency operation

and response procedures are also reviewed annually.

The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the plant Safety Committee.  The Plant coordinates with local Putnam County Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and the City of Palatka HazMat Team.  All are located in Putnam County, Florida.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, and police departments.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the plant.

Montco maintains an ongoing emergency response program in order to efficiently notify and evacuate employees, notify potential residential receptors in the community and initiate state/local emergency response agencies.  The program includes ongoing safety training for employees who respond to releases or potential releases.  The program includes written procedures for proper first aid and emergency medical treatment to treat human exposures; general and specific responsibilities of the site emergency coordinator and site personnel; incident reporting and emergency equipment on site.  The facility emergency response plan is coordinated with the local fire department as required by the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act and the PSM and RMP regulations. 



6.    PERSONNEL (F) (1)

Personnel are the key resource of the plant's prevention program.  Plant employees make up the operators and mechanics who are the emergency operations first responders.  The plant fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the hydrogen chloride system operations including participation in:

?    PSM/RMP safety teams, 

?    Development of the operation procedures, 

?    Hazard evaluations and 

?    On-going training of the operators and other involved staff.

?    Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) Team Members



7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)

Changes to improve safety of 2006,

2009 and 2014 (recommended actions) were identified in the internal and subsequent  audit and the PHA , tour, and audit of the RMP program to meet requirements of the Risk Management Prevention Program.  These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implemented.  An Audit was conducted to review the PSM and RMP program.  The key safety action items were completed.  See the "Update" Section 6 of the Audit Report.  Montco continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the plant management team and process safety team are reviewing potential replacement of anhydrous hydrogen chloride with liquid hydroc;hloric acid to make the system even safer and to prevent a gas release and minimize consequences in the event of a release.
